content: A little late to the party.. but loved it!! :D

Very nice puzzle.

The test "short code" is indeed very relevant.
I would even add a new validator (short code - only one sound):
3
1
3
6
9
CLICK
CLICK
CLICK
→ 1

and a new test (short code) like:
4
1
6
3
8
0
CLACK
CLACK
CLUCK
CLUCK
→ 9
Great idea, wonderful puzzle! Definitely upvote!

I like it! Well set, no blatant bug, interesting! Upvoted!

Solved. Good job on the short codes test, I had a bug there indeed!

I noticed a typo or two in the text, I'll edit that tomorrow if I think of it.

Requests (for approval): there's a trend to require actual test names, even for the validation cases (cf https://www.codingame.com/forum/t/validators-poor-information-ongoing-issue/2011). You might want to edit them, even if it's to copy the test case name.

Suggestions:
- don't quote your constant strings in the problem statement: the formatting is enough to distinguish them.
- you initially ordered the sounds click/clack/clock. it's surprising to order the assumptions of "correct digit" click/clock/clack.
- IMHO, cluck would sound better than clock

Trivial Haskell plea: would you mind capitalizing click/clack/clock so I can trim 8% off my solution's line count?

Note: I didnt have to make use of the "all attempts were unsuccessful" information. Now sure if that's relevant of anything, or would still make for a sensible puzzle.

Crazy thought: what if NO solutions is possible?
Added an example to make things more clear

Thanks for your review !
I've modified the things you pointed out, and as for the "what if NO solutions is possible?" well... it's a safe, you can open it, so there's always a solution :p. But that's a good question so I added a line to clear this out.

That makes sense, thank you :)

Done !
